bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter Reed, October 13, 1901

div1.p: Kean encourages Reed to lobby for the office of Surgeon General.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter Reed, October 13, 1901

opener.dateline:
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA.
OFFICE OF SUPERINTENDENT
DEPARTMENT OF CHARITIES.
HAVANA.
Oct 13th

div1.p:
I returned yesterday
from an inspection trip to
various towns in Santa Cla-
ra province with Gen. Wood
and quite a large party-
I got a chance to have
a heart-to-heart talk
with him & lost no time
in broaching the subject
which I had at heart-
the “vitalization” of the Med.
Corps by the appointment
of a certain Distinguished
Scientist to be S. G. He at
once said in his quick
straightforward way that
2/
he would do every thing
in his power to secure
you the appointment- that
he would talk to the
President about it when
he went north in Nov, &
would urge it - & that he
thought you deserved it
far more than any other
candidate- He also said
that he had already told
the President that he
thought that your dis-
covery was worth the
entire cost of the Spanish
war- He also said
that he was sorry to see
that you were worried
about Gen. S's attitude
in the matter of your discovery and that
3/
you were perfectly safe from all attempts
to rob you of any part of your credit.
He further said that he was going to
mention the matter in a report which
he was going to make in a way that
would make it perfectly clear that
the S. G. had nothing in the world to
do with it- So dont waste another thought on that.
So there - amigo mio - what more do you
wish?- I think OReilly's Havana pull
isnt in it with the lead-pipe which
that you have in things- It is not
necessary to say how happy I am and
how heartily I congratulate you-

Of course many things may happen
in nine months but as far as we can
see at present I think you have your
calling & election sure-

The General seemed to think that we
had better enter you for the race in due
time, so if you will authorize me to do
so, I will about the time that the General
goes north put a neat little paragraph
in the Times & the Army-navy Journal
So as to set people thinking- And dont do any
thing meanwhile to arouse unnecessary antagonism
either of uncle George Miller or the Marine Hospital service-
4/
Just follow the tactics
of Bre'r Rabbit and
keep on saying nothing
for the present-
Your time has not yet
come- After July 1st 1902
you can get out your
snickersull & do what
you want to the U. S. clen
Horse Marines -- but for
the present be wise as
a serpent & harmless as
a dove & let them work
their fake investigations
for all they are worth.
I hope Gral mio that
you will pardon my pre-
suming to advise an E. S.
5/
in this way -- but as I
have constituted myself
your general manager
at this end of the line,
I cant help doing the
duties of my office-

Gorgas gave me a very
interesting account of the
meeting of the P. H. Assn
at Buffalo & how you
laid out that fakir Wasdin-
By the way is it really true
that Sanarelli has given
up the claims of his ba-
cillus? He has an article
I hear in a recent Medical
Journal sustaining them-
Goodbye & congratulations
